question.title: Even Odd Game
question.content:
Given a number, represents number of apples in a bag. You and your friend are playing a game. Both of you are picking one apple turn wise from the bag. It is given that first attempt is always by you. The person picking the last apple will be the winner. Find out the winner if the quantity of apples is given to you as a number.
If you will win: return "You" (without quotes)
If your friend will win: return "Friend" (without quotes)

Examples:

Input: n = 9
Output: You
Input: n = 4
Output: Friend

Constraints:
1 <= n <= 100

rephrased.body: You and your friend are playing a game where you take turns picking apples from a bag. You always go first. The person who picks the last apple wins. Given the initial number of apples in the bag, determine who wins the game.
constraints: 1 <= n <= 100, where n is the initial number of apples

testcases.explanation: You can always pick the last apple to win.
No matter how many apples you pick in the first turn, your friend can always pick the remaining apples to win.

hints:
Java:


if (number % 2 == 0) {
    System.out.print("Friend");
} else {
    System.out.print("You");
}

CPP:

if (number % 2 == 0) {
    cout<<"Friend";
} else {
    cout<<"You";
}

C:

if (number % 2 == 0) {
    printf("Friend");
} else {
    printf("You");
}
